{{Linguistic typology topics}} In [[linguistic typology]], a '''subject–object–verb''' ('''SOV''') language is one in which the [[subject (grammar)|subject]], [[object (grammar)|object]], and [[verb]] of a sentence always or usually appear in that order. If [[English language|English]] were SOV, "Sam oranges ate" would be an ordinary sentence, as opposed to the actual [[Standard English]] "Sam ate oranges". The term is often loosely used for [[ergative language]]s like [[Adyghe language|Adyghe]] and [[Basque language|Basque]] that really have [[agent (grammar)|agents]] instead of subjects. ==Incidence== {{Language word order frequency}} Among [[natural language]]s with a word order preference, SOV is the most common type (followed by [[subject–verb–object]]; the two types account for more than 75% of natural languages with a preferred order).{{cite book | last = Crystal | first = David | authorlink = David Crystal | title = The Cambridge Encyclopedia of Language | edition = 2nd | year = 1997 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | location = Cambridge | isbn = 0-521-55967-7}} Languages that have SOV structure include [[Ainu language|Ainu]], [[Akkadian language|Akkadian]], [[Amharic language|Amharic]], [[Armenian language|Armenian]], [[Assamese language|Assamese]], [[Aymara language|Aymara]], [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Basque language|Basque]], [[Bengali language|Bengali]], [[Burmese language|Burmese]], [[Burushaski language|Burushaski]], [[Cherokee language|Cherokee]], [[Dakota language|Dakota]], [[Dogon languages]], [[Elamite language|Elamite]], [[Ancient Greek]], [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]], [[Hajong language|Hajong]], [[Hindi language|Hindi]], [[Hittite language|Hittite]], [[Hopi language|Hopi]], [[Ijoid languages]], [[Itelmen language|Itelmen]], [[Japanese language|Japanese]], [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]], [[Kyrgyz language|Kyrgyz]], [[Korean language|Korean]], [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]], [[Latin language|Classical Latin]], [[Lakota language|Lakota]], [[Manchu language|Manchu]], [[Mande languages]], [[Marathi language|Marathi]], [[Mongolian language|Mongolian]], [[Navajo language|Navajo]], [[Nepali language|Nepali]], [[Nepal Bhasa|Newari]], [[Nivkh language|Nivkh]], [[Nobiin language|Nobiin]], [[Pāli]], [[Pashto language|Pashto]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], [[Quechua language|Quechua]], [[Senufo languages]], [[Seri language|Seri]], [[Sicilian language|Sicilian]], [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]], [[Sinhalese language|Sinhalese]], [[Sunwar language|Sunuwar]] and most other [[Indo-Iranian languages]], [[Somali language|Somali]] and virtually all other [[Cushitic languages]], [[Sumerian language|Sumerian]], [[Standard Tibetan|Tibetan]] and nearly all other [[Tibeto-Burman languages]], [[Kannada language|Kannada]], [[Malayalam language|Malayalam]], [[Tamil language|Tamil]], [[Telugu Language|Telugu]] and all other [[Dravidian languages|Dravidian]] languages, [[Tigrinya language|Tigrinya]], [[Turkic languages]], [[Turkish Language|Turkish]], [[Urdu language|Urdu]], almost all [[Uto-Aztecan languages]], [[Uzbek language|Uzbek]], [[Yukaghir language|Yukaghir]], and virtually all [[Caucasian languages]]. [[Standard Chinese|Standard Mandarin]] is SVO, but for simple sentences with a clear context, word order is flexible enough to allow for SOV or OSV. [[German language|German]] and [[Dutch language|Dutch]] are considered SVO in conventional typology and SOV in [[generative grammar]]. For example, in German, a basic sentence such as "Ich sage etwas über Karl" ("I say something about Karl") is in SVO word order. When a noun clause marker like "dass" or "wer" (in English, "that" or "who" respectively) is used, the verb appears at the end of the sentence for the word order SOV. A possible example in SOV word order would be "Ich sage, dass Karl einen Gürtel gekauft hat." (A literal English translation would be "I say that Karl a belt bought has.") This is [[V2 word order]]. A rare example of SOV word order in English is "I (subject) thee (object) wed (verb)" in the wedding vow "With this ring, I thee wed."Andreas Fischer, "'With this ring I thee wed': The verbs to wed and to marry in the history of English". Language History and Linguistic Modelling: A Festschrift for Jacek Fisiak on his 60th Birthday. Ed. Raymond Hickey and Stanislaw Puppel. Trends in Linguistics, Studies and Monographs 101 (Berlin, New York: Mouton de Gruyter, 1997), pp.467-81 ==Properties== SOV languages have a strong tendency to use [[postposition]]s rather than [[preposition]]s, to place [[auxiliary verb]]s after the action verb, to place [[genitive]] noun phrases before the possessed noun, to place a name before a title or [[honorific]] ("James Uncle" and "Johnson Doctor" rather than "Uncle James" and "Doctor Johnson") and to have subordinators appear at the end of subordinate clauses. They have a weaker but significant tendency to place [[demonstrative]] adjectives before the nouns they modify. [[Relative clause]]s preceding the nouns to which they refer usually signals SOV word order, but the reverse does not hold: SOV languages feature prenominal and postnominal relative clauses roughly equally. SOV languages also seem to exhibit a tendency towards using a [[time–manner–place]] ordering of [[adpositional phrase]]s. In linguistic typology one can usefully distinguish two types of SOV languages in terms of their type of marking: # [[dependent-marking language|dependent-marking]] has [[case (linguistics)|case]] [[marker (linguistics)|markers]] to distinguish the subject and the object, which allows it to use the variant OSV word order without ambiguity. This type usually places [[adjective]]s and [[numeral (linguistics)|numeral]]s before the nouns they modify and is exclusively suffixing without prefixes. SOV languages of this first type include [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and [[Tamil language|Tamil]]. # [[head-marking language|head-marking]] distinguishes subject and object by [[affix]]es on the verb rather than markers on the nouns. It also differs from the dependent-marking SOV language in using [[prefix]]es as well as suffixes, usually for [[grammatical tense|tense]] and [[possession (linguistics)|possession]]. Because adjectives in this type are much more verb-like than in dependent-marking SOV languages, they usually follow the nouns. In most SOV languages with a significant level of head-marking or verb-like adjectives, numerals and related quantifiers (like "all", "every") also follow the nouns they modify. Languages of this type include [[Navajo language|Navajo]] and [[Seri language|Seri]]. In practice, of course, the distinction between these two types is far from sharp. Many SOV languages are substantially [[double-marking language|double-marking]] and tend to exhibit properties intermediate between the two idealised types above. Many languages that have shifted to SVO-word order from the original SOV retain (at least to an extent) the properties, for example the Finnish language (high usage of postpositions etc.) ==Examples== === Albanian === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Agimi librin e mori. |- ! Words |Agimi || librin || e mori |- ! [[Gloss (annotation)#In linguistics|Gloss]] | Agimi || the book || took |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Agimi took the book. (It was Agimi who took the book) |} === Azerbaijani === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" |Ümid ağac əkəcək. |- ! Words |Ümid || ağac || əkəcək |- ! Gloss | Umid || tree || will plant |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Umid will plant a tree. |} ===Armenian=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" |Իմ անունը Շուշանիկ է։ |- ! Words |Իմ || անունը || Շուշանիկ || է |- ! [[Romanization of Armenian|Romanization]] |Im || anunȳ || Šušanik || ē |- ! Gloss | My || name || Shushanik || is |- ! Parts | colspan="2" | Subject | Object | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | My name is Shushanik. |} === Basque === [[Basque language|Basque]] in short sentences, usually, subject or agent–object–'''verb'''; in long sentences, usually, subject or agent-'''verb'''-objects): {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" |Enekok sagarra '''ekarri du'''. |- ! Words |Enekok || sagarra || ekarri ||du |- ! Gloss | Eneko (+ERGative) || the apple || brought (to bring) || AUX has |- ! Parts | Agent | Object | colspan="2" | '''Verb''' |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Eneko has brought the apple |} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" |Eneritzek '''eskatu du''' inork irakurri nahi ez zuen liburua |- ! Words |Eneritzek ||eskatu ||du ||+ + + |- ! Gloss | Eneritz (+ERGative) ||asked for|| AUX has||+ + + |- ! Parts | Agent | colspan="2" | '''Verb''' | Objects |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Eneritz requested the book nobody wanted to read |} === Bengali === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Sentence | colspan="6" style="text-align:left" | আমি ভাত খাই |- ! Words | colspan="2"|'''আমি''' | colspan="2"|'''ভাত''' | colspan="2"|'''খাই''' |- ! [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] | colspan="2"| {{IPA|ami}}
ami | colspan="2"| {{IPA|bʰat}}
bhat | colspan="2"| {{IPA|kʰai}}
khai |- ! Gloss | '''I '''|| (subj)|| '''rice'''|| (obj) || '''eat''' || (pres) |- ! Parts | colspan="2" | Subject | colspan="2" | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="6" style="text-align:left" | I eat rice. |} === Burmese === [[Burmese language|Burmese]] is an [[analytic language]]. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Sentence | colspan="6" style="text-align:left" | {{my|'''ငါ'''က '''စက္ကူဘူး'''ကို '''ဖွင့်'''တယ်။}} |- ! Words | {{my|'''ငါ'''}} || {{my|က}} || {{my|'''စက္ကူဘူး'''}} || {{my|ကို}} || {{my|'''ဖွင့်'''}} || {{my|တယ်}} |- ! [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] | {{IPA|ŋà}}
nga || {{IPA|ɡa̰}}
ga. || {{IPA|seʔkù bú}}
se'ku bu: ||{{IPA|ɡò}}
gou || {{IPA|pʰwìɴ}}
hpwin. || {{IPA|dè}}
de |- ! Gloss | '''I '''|| (subj)|| '''box'''|| (obj) || '''open''' || (pres) |- ! Parts | colspan="2" | Subject | colspan="2" | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="6" style="text-align:left" | I open the box. |} === Chinese === Generally, [[varieties of Chinese|Chinese varieties]] all feature SVO word order. However, especially in [[Standard Chinese|Standard Mandarin]], SOV is tolerated as well. There is even a special structure to form an SOV sentence. Note that SOV is generally used to emphasize the object, such as in this case, where the apple is a very specific apple. SOV structure is also widely used in railway contact in order to clarify the objective of the order.{{cite thesis|title=车机联控语言——铁路行车领域“共同语言”的研究|url=https://wenku.baidu.com/view/832c1d110b4e767f5acfce6d.html|language=zh}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="4" style="text-align:left" | 我把苹果吃了. |- ! Words | 我 || 把 || 苹果 ||吃了. |- ! [[Transliteration]] | Wǒ || bǎ || píngguǒ || chīle |- ! Gloss | I || sign for moving object before the verb || apple || ate |- ! Parts | Subject | Sign | Object | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="4" style="text-align:left" | I ate the apple. (The apple we were talking about earlier) |- ! colspan=5| |- ! Sentence | colspan="4" style="text-align:left" | 电力客车直100次上海站停车. |- ! Words | 电力客车直100次 || 上海站 || 停车. || |- ! [[Transliteration]] | Diànlì kèchē zhí yībǎi cì || Shànghǎi zhàn || tíngchē || |- ! Gloss | [[Shanghai-Kowloon Through Train|Electrified passenger train No. Z100]] || [[Shanghai Railway Station|Shanghai Station]] || Stop || |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | Verb | |- ! Translation | colspan="4" style="text-align:left" | Electrified passenger train No. Z100: stop at Shanghai Station |- |} Furthermore, in [[Standard Chinese|Standard Mandarin]], SOV is used in the passive voice, where the object of the active sentence becomes the subject of the passive sentence, and the subject of the active sentence becomes the object of the passive sentence. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | 苹果被我吃了. |- ! Words | 苹果 || 被 || 我 || 吃 ||了. |- ! [[Transliteration]] | Píngguǒ || bèi || wǒ || chī || le |- ! Gloss | Apple || sign for passive voice || I || eat || particle for completed action |- ! Parts | Subject | Sign | Object | Verb | Particle |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | The apple is eaten by me. (The apple we were talking about earlier) |- |} === Dutch === [[Dutch language|Dutch]] is SOV combined with [[V2 word order]]. The non-finite verb (infinitive or participle) remains in final position, but the finite (i.e. inflected) verb is moved to the second position. Simple verbs look like [[subject–verb–object|SVO]], non-finite verbs (participles, infinitives) and compound verbs follow this pattern: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Ik wil je helpen. |- ! Parts | Ik || wil || je || helpen |- ! Gloss | I || want to || you || help |- ! Parts | subject || fin.verb || object || nonfin.verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | I want to help you. |} Pure SOV order is found in subordinate clauses: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="7" style="text-align:left" | Ik zei dat ik je wil helpen. |- ! Parts | Ik || zei || dat || ik || je || wil || helpen |- ! Gloss | I || said || that || I || you || want || to help |- ! Parts | subject || fin.verb || subord. conj. || subject || object || fin.verb || nonfin.verb |- ! Translation | colspan="7" style="text-align:left" | I said that I want to help you. |} === French === The [[French language]] usually uses a subject–verb–object structure but places [[Clitic|proclitics]] before the verb when using most pronouns, which is sometimes mistaken for SOV word order. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" |Nous les avons. |- ! Parts |Nous || les-avons. |- ! Gloss | We || them/those-have |- ! Parts | Subject | colspan="2" | Object-Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="4" style="text-align:left" | We have those/them |} === Georgian === The [[Georgian language]] isn't extremely rigid with regards to word order, but is typically either SOV or SVO. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" |მე ქართველი ვარ. |- ! Transliteration | colspan="4" | me kartveli var |- ! Parts |მე || ქართველი || ვარ. |- ! Gloss | I || Georgian || [I] am |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="4" style="text-align:left" | I am (a) Georgian. |} === German === [[German language|German]] is SOV combined with [[V2 word order]]. The non-finite verb (infinitive or participle) remains in final position, but the finite (i.e. inflected) verb is moved to the second position. Simple verbs look like [[subject–verb–object|SVO]], compound verbs follow this pattern: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" | Er hat einen Apfel gegessen. |- ! Words | Er || hat || einen Apfel || gegessen. |- ! Gloss | He || has ||an apple || eaten. |- ! Parts | Subject || Auxiliary || Object || Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | He has eaten an apple. |} The word order changes also depending on whether the phrase is a [[main clause]] or a [[dependent clause]]. In dependent clauses, the word order is always entirely SOV (cf. also [[Inversion (linguistics)|Inversion]]): {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Subordinate Clause | colspan="5" | Weil Horst einen Apfel gegessen hat. |- ! Words | Weil || Horst || einen Apfel || gegessen || hat. |- ! Gloss | Because || Horst ||an apple || eaten || has. |- ! Parts | Conjunction || Subject || Object || Verb || Auxiliary |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Because Horst has eaten an apple. |} === [[Ancient Greek|Greek (Classical)]] === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="3" style="text-align:left" | ὁ ἀνὴρ τòν παĩδα φιλεῖ. |- ! Words |ὁ ανήρ (ho anḗr) || τòν παĩδα (tòn paîda) || φιλεῖ (phileî). |- ! Gloss | The man || the child || loves. |- ! Parts | Subject || Object || Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="3" style="text-align:left" | The man loves the child. |} === Hajong === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | '''Moi''' '''hugre'm'''re' '''kha'''sei. |- ! Words | '''Moi''' || '''hugre'm''' || re' || '''kha''' ||sei. |- ! Gloss | '''I''' || '''guava''' || (accusative) || '''eat''' ||(past tense, indicative) |- ! Parts | colspan="1" | Subject | colspan="2" | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="6" style="text-align:left" | I ate the guava. |} 're'' is a particle that indicates the accusative case and 'sei' indicates past tense declarative. Here, 'e'' is pronounced as the 'i' in 'g'''i'''rl' and 'ei' is pronounced as the 'ay' in 's'''ay''''. === Hindi === {| class="wikitable" !Sentence | colspan="4" |मैं सेब खाता हूं |- !Words |मैं |सेब |खाता |हूं |- ![[Romanization]] |main |seb |khaataa |hun |- !Gloss |I |an apple |eat (pcp. pres. act. m.) |am |- !Parts |Subject | colspan="2" |Object |Verb |- !Translation | colspan="4" |I eat an apple. |} === Hungarian === [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] word order is free, although the meaning slightly changes. Almost all permutations of the following sample are valid, but with stress on different parts of the meaning. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Pista kenyeret szeletel. |- ! Words |Pista || kenyeret || szeletel |- ! Gloss | Pista || bread || slices |- ! Parts | '''S'''ubject | '''O'''bject | colspan="2" | '''V'''erb |- ! Translation  | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Pista slices bread. |} === Italian === The [[Italian language]] usually uses a subject–verb–object structure, but when an enclitic pronoun is used, this comes before the verb and the auxiliary. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Io la sto mangiando |- ! Parts | Io || la || sto || mangiando |- ! Gloss | I || it || am || eating |- ! Parts | Subject || Object || Auxiliary || Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="4" style="text-align:left" | I am eating it |} === Japanese === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Sentence | colspan="6" style="text-align:left" | '''私'''が'''箱'''を'''開け'''ます。 |- ! Words | '''私''' || が || '''箱''' || を || '''開け'''ます。 |- ! [[Romanization]] | '''watashi''' || ga || '''hako''' || (w)o || '''ake'''masu. |- ! Gloss | '''I''' || (sub) || '''box''' || (obj) || '''open'''([[honorific speech in Japanese#Polite language|polite]]) |- ! Parts | colspan="2" | Subject | colspan="2" | Object | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | I (am the one who) open(s) the box. |} The markers が (ga) and を ((w)o) are, respectively, subject and object markers for the words that precede them. Technically, the sentence could be translated a number of ways ("'''I''' open a box", "It is I who open the boxes", etc.), but this does not affect the SOV analysis. Japanese has some flexibility in word order, so an OSV is also possible. ('''箱'''を'''私'''が'''開け'''ます。) === Kannada === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | ನಾನು ಮನೆ ಕಟ್ಟಿದೆನು . |- ! Words |ನಾನು || ಮನೆ || ಕಟ್ಟಿದೆನು |- ! [[Transliteration]] |Naanu || mane || kaTTidenu |- ! Gloss | I|| the house || built |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | I built the house. |} === Kashmiri === Like German and Dutch the Indo-Aryan language [[Kashmiri language|Kashmiri]] is SOV combined with [[V2 word order]]. The non-finite verb (infinitive or participle) remains in final position, but the finite (i.e. inflected) part of the verb appears in second position. Simple verbs look like [[subject–verb–object|SVO]], whereas auxiliated verbs are discontinuous and adhere to this pattern: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="6" style="text-align:left" | کور چہے ثونٹہ کہیوان |- ! Transcription | kuur || chhi || tsũũţh || khyevaan |- ! Gloss | girl || is || apples || eating |- ! Parts | Subject || Auxiliary || Object || Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="6" style="text-align:left" | The girl is eating apples. |} Since Kashmiri is a [[V2 word order|V2 language]] if the word ''tsũũţh'' 'apple' comes first then the subject ''kuur'' 'girl' must follow the auxiliary ''chhi'' 'is': ''tsũũţh chhi kuur khyevaan'' [Lit. "Apples is girl eating."] The word order changes also depending on whether the phrase is in a [[main clause]] or in certain kinds of [[dependent clause]]. For instance, in '''[[relative clauses]]''', the word order is SOVAux: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Main clause + Subordinate Clause | colspan="9" style="text-align:left" | میے ان سوہ کور '''یوس ثونٹہ کہیوان چہے ''' |- ! Transcription | => || mye || eny || swa kuur || => || '''ywas''' || '''tsũũţh''' || '''khyevaan''' || '''chhi''' |- ! Gloss | => || I || brought || that girl || => || who || apples || eating || is |- ! Parts | Main clause => || Subject || Verb || Object || Relative clause => || Subject || Object || Verb || Auxiliary |- ! Translation | colspan="9" style="text-align:left" | I brought the girl '''who is eating apples'''. |} === Kazakh === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Дастан кітап оқыды. |- ! Words |Дастан || кітап || оқыды |- ! Transliteration |Dastan || kitap || oqıdı |- ! Gloss | Dastan || a book || read |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Dastan read a book. |} Like in Japanese, OSV is possible too. (Кітапті Дастан оқыды.) === Korean === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Sentence | colspan="6" style="text-align:left" | '''내'''가 '''상자'''를 '''연'''다.
'''내'''가 '''箱子'''를 '''연'''다. |- ! Words | '''내'''|| 가 || '''상자'''
'''箱子''' || 를 || '''여(ㄹ)''' ||-ㄴ다. |- ! [[Romanization]] | '''nae''' || ga || '''sangja''' || reul || '''yeo(l)''' || -nda. |- ! Gloss | '''I''' || (nominative) || '''box''' || (accusative) || '''open''' ||(present tense, indicative) |- ! Parts | colspan="2" | Subject | colspan="2" | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="6" style="text-align:left" | I open the box. |} '가 (ga)/이 (i)' is a particle that indicates the nominative case. '를 (reul)/을 (eul)' is a particle that indicates the accusative case. '-ㄴ다 (nda)' indicates present tense declarative. The consonant 'ㄹ (l)' in the verb stem (열-) is dropped before the suffix. ※ Here, '나 (na, [[I (pronoun)]])' is changed to '내 (nae)' before '가 (ga)'. === Kyrgyz === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Биз алма жедик |- ! Words |Биз||алма||жедик |- ! Transliteration |Biz||alma||jedik |- ! Gloss |We||an apple||ate |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" |We ate an apple |} === Latin === {{main|Latin word order}} [[Classical Latin]] was an [[inflected language]] and had a very flexible word order and sentence structure, but the most usual word order in formal prose was SOV. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Sentence | colspan="6" style="text-align:center" | Servus puellam amat |- ! Words | Servus || puellam || amat |- ! Gloss | Slave (nom) || girl (acc) || loves |- ! Parts | Subject || Object || Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="3" style="text-align:left" | The slave loves the girl. |} Again, there are multiple valid translations (such as "a slave") that do not affect the overall analysis. === Malayalam === {| class="wikitable" !Sentence | colspan="4" |ഞാൻ പുസ്തകത്തെ എടുത്തു. |- !Words |ഞാൻ |പുസ്തകം |എ |എടുത്തു |- ![[Transliteration]] |ñān |pustakam̥ |(-e) (accusative)* |eṭuttu |- !Gloss |I |(the) book |took | |- !Parts |Subject |Object |Verb | |- !Translation | colspan="4" |I took the book. |} *Pustakam̥ + -e = pustakatte (പുസ്തകത്തെ) === Manchu === {| class="wikitable" !Sentence | colspan="4" |{{MongolUnicode|lang=mnc|ᠪᡳ ᠪᡠᡩᠠ ᠪᡝ ᠵᡝᠮᠪᡳ}} |- !Words |{{MongolUnicode|lang=mnc|ᠪᡳ}} |{{MongolUnicode|lang=mnc|ᠪᡠᡩᠠ}} |{{MongolUnicode|lang=mnc|ᠪᡝ}} |{{MongolUnicode|lang=mnc|ᠵᡝᠮᠪᡳ}} |- ![[Transliteration]] |bi |buda |be |jembi |- !Gloss |I |meal |''(accusative)'' |eat |- !Parts |Subject |Object |Grammatical marker |Verb |- !Translation | colspan="4" |I eat a meal. |} === Marathi === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | तो बियाणे पेरतो. |- ! Words |तो || बियाणे || पेरतो |- ! [[Transliteration]] | Tō || biyāṇē || pēratō |- |- ! [[Gloss (annotation)#In linguistics|Gloss]] | he || seeds || sows |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | He sows seeds. |} === Mongolian === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Би ном уншив. |- ! Words |Би || ном || уншив |- ! [[Transliteration]] | Bi || nom || unshiv |- |- ! [[Gloss (annotation)#In linguistics|Gloss]] | I || a book || read |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | I read a book. |} === Ossetian === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Алан чиныг кæсы. |- ! Words |Алан || чиныг || кæсы |- ! [[Transliteration]] | Alan || činyg || kæsy |- ! [[Gloss (annotation)#In linguistics|Gloss]] | Alan || book || reads |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Alan reads a book. |} === Pashto === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="3" style="text-align:left" | .زه کار کوم |- !Words | زه || کار || کوم |- ! Gloss | زه (Subject Pronoun) || کار (Noun) || کوم (verb) |- ! [[Transliteration]] | Zə || kaar || kawum |- ! Parts | Subject || Object || Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="3" style="text-align:left" | I do the work. |} === Persian === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="3" style="text-align:left" | .من سیب می‌خورم |- !Words | من||سیب||می‌خورم |- ! Gloss | I ||apple ||eat (first person present tense) |- ! [[Transliteration]] | man || seeb || mikhoram |- ! Parts | Subject || Object || Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="3" style="text-align:left" | I am eating an apple. |} === Portuguese === [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] is an SVO language, but it has some SOV constructs. In case of [[Portuguese_personal_pronouns#Proclisis.2C_enclisis.2C_and_mesoclisis|proclisis]]: ''Todos aqui te amam''. Literally: ''Everybody here loves you''. ''Aquilo me entristeceu''. Literally: ''It saddened me''. When using a temporal adverb, optionally with the negative: ''Nós já [não] os temos''. Literally: ''We already [not] them have''. Meaning: (Positive) ''We already have them''. (Negative) ''We do not have them anymore.'' ''Nós ainda [não] os temos''. Literally: ''We still [not] them have''. Meaning: (Positive) ''We still have them''. (Negative) ''We have do not them yet.''. When answering the phone: ''Sim, sou eu''. Literally: ''Yes, am I''. Meaning: ''Yes, it's I'' SVO form: ''Sou eu mesmo/mesma'', literally "It's me [indeed]". There is an [[infix]] construction for the [[Future tense|future]] and [[Conditional tense|conditional]] tenses: ''Eu fá-lo-ei amanhã''. Literally: ''I do-it-will tomorrow''. Meaning: ''I will do it tomorrow''. SVO form: ''Eu hei-de fazê-lo amanhã'' or ''eu farei o mesmo amanhã'' On composed sentences, it is also allowed the SOV order for the last part in some situations like: ''Ela não os comeu, mas comi-os eu''. Literally: ''She did not eat them, but ate them I''. Meaning: ''She did not eat them, but I did''. SVO form: ''Ela não comeu os mesmos, mas eu comi [a eles]''. === Punjabi === {| class="wikitable" !Sentence | colspan="4" |ਮੈਨੂੰ ਇੱਕ ਸੇਬ ਚਾਹੀਦਾ ਹੈ। |- !Words |ਮੈਨੂੰ |ਇੱਕ |ਸੇਬ |ਚਾਹੀਦਾ ਹੈ |- ![[Romanization]] |mainu |ikk |seb |chaahida hai |- !Gloss |I(dative) |an |apple |want |- !Parts |Subject | colspan="2" |Object |Verb |- !Translation | colspan="4" |I want an apple. |} === Russian === [[Russian language|Russian]] is an [[inflected language]] and very flexible in word order; it allows all possible word combinations. However, it is generally considered a SVO language. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Sentence | colspan="6" style="text-align:center" | Она его любит |- ! Words | Она || его || любит |- ! [[Transliteration]] | aná || yevó || lyúbit |- ! Gloss | she (nom) || him (acc) || loves |- ! Parts | Subject || Object || Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="3" style="text-align:left" | She loves him |} for example: Она любит его, любит его oна, любит oна его, and virtually all re-orderings of Russian sentence order are correct although this is often used in different situations to emphasize particular constituents of a sentence. Who loves him? 'she' is the one who loves him (emphatic meaning). In this way any part of the sentence can be emphasized without changing basic meaning (a convenience created by Russian's noun case system) === Sanskrit === [[Saṃskṛtam]] is an inflected language and very flexible in word order; it allows all possible word combinations. However, it is generally considered a SOV language. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | [[tat tvam asi]] |- ! Words |tat || tvam|| asi |- ! [[Gloss (annotation)#In linguistics|Gloss]] | that || you || are |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | That you are. |} === Somali === [[Somali language|Somali]] generally uses the subject–object–verb structure when speaking formally. {| class="wikitable" !Sentence | colspan="4" |Aniga baa albaabka furay |- !Words |Aniga |baa |albaab(ka) |furay |- !Gloss |I |[[Focus (linguistics)|Focus]] |(the) door |opened |- !Parts | colspan="2" |Subject |Object |Verb |- !Translation | colspan="4" |I opened the door |} === Spanish === The [[Spanish language]] usually uses a subject–verb–object structure, but when an enclitic pronoun is used, this comes before the verb and the auxiliary. Sometimes, in dual-verb constructions involving the infinitive and the gerund, the enclitic pronoun can be put before both verbs, or attached to the end of the second verb. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Yo lo como |- ! Parts | Yo || lo || como |- ! Gloss | I || it || eat |- ! Parts | Subject || Object || Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="4" style="text-align:left" | I eat it |} === Talysh === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" |Merd kitob handedə. |- ! Words |Merd || kitob || handedə |- ! Gloss | Man || book || reading |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | The man is reading a book. |} === Tamil === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Sentence | colspan="6" style="text-align:left" | '''நான்''' தான் '''பெட்டி'''யை திறப்பேன். |- ! Words | '''நான்''' || தான் || '''பெட்டி''' || யை || '''திற'''ப்பேன்。 |- ! [[Romanization]] | '''Nān''' || tān || '''peṭṭi''' || yai || '''tiṟa'''ppēn. |- ! Gloss | '''I''' || (nominative) || '''box''' || (accusative) || '''open'''(indicative verb) |- ! Parts | colspan="2" | Subject | colspan="2" | Object | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | I (am the one who) open(s) the box. |} The தான் (tān) and யை (yai) are, respectively, nominative and accusative markers for the subject and object that respectively precede them. The தான் (tān) is optional in the [[Tamil language]]. The sentence may literally be translated as 'I [who am] the box [which] open shall.' The sentence may also be translated, although less frequently, as பெட்டியை நான் தான் திறப்பேன் (Peṭṭiyai nāṉ tāṉ tiṟappēn), or simply, பெட்டியை திறப்பேன் (Peṭṭiyai tiṟappēn) as Tamil is a null-subject language because the indicative verb at the end of the word indicates the 1st person subject. This follows the object-subject-verb (OSV) pattern. === Telugu === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Sentence | colspan="3" style="text-align:left" | నేను పార్టీకి వెళ్తున్నాను. |- ! Words | నేను || పార్టీకి || వెళ్తున్నాను. |- ! [[Transliteration]] | Nēnu || pārtīki || veḷtunnānu. |- ! Gloss | I || to party || am going. |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="3" style="text-align:left" | I am going to the party. |} === Tigrinya === The [[Tigrinya language]] usually uses a subject–verb–object structure. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | ዳኒኤል ኩዑሶ ቀሊዑ |- ! Words | ዳኒኤል || ኩዑሶ|| ቀሊዑ |- ! Gloss | Daniel || ball || kicked |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Daniel kicked the ball. |} === Turkish === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Yusuf elmayı yedi. |- ! Words |Yusuf || elmayı || yedi |- ! Gloss | Joseph || the apple || ate |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Joseph ate the apple. |} Like all other [[Turkic languages]], Turkish has flexibility in word order, so any order is possible. For example, in addition to the SOV order above, this sentence could also be constructed as OSV (''Elmayı Yusuf yedi.''), OVS (''Elmayı yedi Yusuf.''), VSO (''Yedi Yusuf elmayı.''), VOS (''Yedi elmayı Yusuf.''), or SVO (''Yusuf yedi elmayı.''), but these other orders carry a connotation of emphasis of importance on either the subject, object, or the verb. The SOV order is the "default" one that does not connote particular emphasis on any part of the sentence. === Udmurt === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" |мoн книгa лыӟӥcькo. |- ! Words |мoн|| книгa || лыӟӥcькo. |- ! [[Romanization]] |mon|| kniga || lyjis'ko |- ! Gloss | I || a book || to read |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | I am reading a book. |} === Urdu === {| class="wikitable" !Sentence | colspan="4" |.میں نے اسے دیکھا |- !Words |میں |نے |اسے |دیکھا |- ![[Romanization]] |main |ne |use |dekha |- !Gloss | colspan="2" |I(ergative) |him/her |saw |- !Parts | colspan="2" |Subject |Object |Verb |- !Translation | colspan="4" |I saw him/her. |} === Uzbek === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Sentence | colspan="6" style="text-align:left" | Anvar Xivaga ketdi. |- ! Words | Anvar || Xiva'''ga''' || ketdi. |- ! Gloss | Anvar (nom) || to Khiva (dat) || went |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Anvar went to Khiva. |} The marker "ga" is a dative case marker for the object that precedes it. Due to flexibility in word order in [[Uzbek language|Uzbek]], it is possible to transform the sentence into OSV as well ("Xivaga Anvar ketdi" / "It was Anvar who went to Khiva"). === Yi === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" |ꉢꌧꅪꋠ. |- ! Words | ꉢ || ꌧꅪ || ꋠ . |- ! Romaniz. |nga||syp-hni||zze. |- ! Gloss | I || (an) apple || (to) eat. |- ! Parts | Subject | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | I eat an apple. |} === Zarma === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Sentence | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" |Hama na mo ŋwa . |- ! Words |Hama || na || mo || ŋwa |- ! Gloss | Hama || ''(completed aspect)'' || rice || eat |- ! Parts | Subject | Grammatical marker | Object | colspan="2" | Verb |- ! Translation | colspan="5" style="text-align:left" | Hama ate rice. |} ==See also== *[[Topic-prominent language]] *[[Subject–verb–object]] *[[Object–subject–verb]] *[[Object–verb–subject]] *[[Verb–object–subject]] *[[Verb–subject–object]] *[[:Category:Subject–object–verb languages]] *[[Reverse Polish notation]], a mathematical notation in which [[Operation (mathematics)|operators]] follow their [[Operand|operands]], e.g., 3 4 + ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Subject-object-verb}} [[Category:Subject–object–verb languages| ]] [[Category:Word order]]

{{distinguish|Timor–Alor–Pantar languages}}
{{Infobox language family |name=Timoric |altname=Timor–Babar |region=[[Indonesia]] |familycolor=Austronesian |fam2=[[Malayo-Polynesian languages|Malayo-Polynesian]] (MP) |fam3=[[Nuclear Malayo-Polynesian languages|Nuclear MP]] |fam4=([[Central–Eastern Malayo-Polynesian languages|Central–Eastern]]) |children=(disputed) |glotto=none |glotto2=timo1260 |glottoname2=Ramelaic |glotto3=timo1259 |glottoname3=Fabronic/Extra-Ramelaic }}
The '''Timoric''', or sometimes '''Timor–Babar''', languages are a group of fifty [[Austronesian languages]] (geographically [[Central–Eastern Malayo-Polynesian languages]]) spoken on the islands of [[Timor]], neighboring [[Wetar Island|Wetar]], and (depending on the classification) the [[Babar Islands]] to the east.
Within the group, the languages with the most speakers are [[Uab Meto]] of [[West Timor]] and [[Tetum]] of [[East Timor]], each with about half a million speakers, though in addition Tetum is an official language and a lingua franca among non-Tetum East Timorese.
==Languages== Unclassified [[Nauete language|Nauete]] is not close to other Timorese languages. [[Habu language|Habu]] is structurally similar to [[Waima'a language|Waima'a]].
The Babar languages form their own group: * [[Babar languages]] (see)
===Hull (1998)=== [[Geoffrey Hull]] (1998) proposes a Timoric group as follows:
*Ramelaic (near the [[Ramelau]] range) **West: [[Kemak language|Kemak]], [[Tukudede language|Tukudede]] **Central: [[Mambai language (Timor)|Mambai]] **East (Idalaka): [[Idaté language|Idaté]], [[Isní language|Isní]], [[Lakalei language|Lakalei]], [[Lolein language|Lolein]] *Extra-Ramelaic (Fabronic; whatever is not Ramelaic) **West: [[Dawan language|Dawan]] (Uab Meto)–[[Amarasi language|Amarasi]], [[Helong language|Helong]], Roti ([[Bilba language|Bilba]], [[Dengka language|Dengka]], [[Lole language|Lole]], [[Ringgou language|Ringgou]], [[Dela-Oenale language|Dela-Oenale]], [[Termanu language|Termanu]], [[Tii language|Tii]]) **Central: [[Tetun language|Tetun]], [[Bekais language|Bekais]] **North: [[Wetar language|Wetar]], [[Galoli language|Galoli]] **East: [[Kairui language|Kairui]], [[Waimoa language|Waimaha]], [[Midiki language|Midiki]]; [[Luang language|Luang]], [[Makuva language|Makuva]]
===Van Engelenhoven === Van Engelenhoven sets up a South–East Timor branch including Tetun, Waimaha, and Luangic–Kisaric; the latter is as follows:<ref>Adelaar 2005:26</ref>
*South–East Timor ** Tetun ** Waimaha **Luangic–Kisaric ***Kisar–Roma: [[Kisar language|Kisar]], [[Romang language|Romang]] ***Luangic: [[Luang language|Luang]], [[Wetan language|Wetan]], [[Leti language|Leti]]
===Taber (1993)=== [[Image:Timor Sprache.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Languages of [[Timor Island]]]] Taber (1993:396) gives a Southwest Maluku and Babar group as follows, along with West Damar as an isolate.
*Southwest Maluku group **''[[East Damar language|East Damar]]'' **Wetar subgroup ***''[[Galoli language|Talur]]'' ***[[Wetarese language|Wetar]] cluster ****''Aputai'' ****''Perai'' ****''Tugun'' ****''Iliun'' **Kisar-Roma subgroup ***''[[Kisar language|Kisar]]'' ***''[[Romang language|Roma]]'' **Luang ***''[[Leti language|Leti]]'' ***''[[Luang language|Luang]]'' ***''[[Wetan language|Wetan]]'' **TNS (Teun-Nila-Serua) subgroup ***''[[Te’un language|Teun]]'' ***Nila-Serua cluster: ''[[Nila language|Nila]]'', ''[[Serua language|Serua]]'' *Babar group **North Babar subgroup ***''[[North Babar language|North Babar]]'' ***''[[Dai language (Austronesian)|Dai]]'' ***''[[Dawera-Daweloor language|Dawera-Daweloor]]'' **South Babar subgroup ***Southwest Babar cluster ****''[[Emplawas language|Emplawas]]'' ****''[[Tela-Masbuar language|Tela-Masbuar]]'' ****''[[Imroing language|Imroing]]'' ***Masela – Southeast Babar cluster ****''[[Southeast Babar language|Southeast Babar]]'' ****''[[Serili language|Serili]]'' ****''[[East Masela language|East Masela]]'' ****''[[Central Masela language|Central Masela]]'' *''[[West Damar language|West Damar]]'' (isolate)
==References== {{Reflist}} * Hull, Geoffrey. 1998. "The basic lexical affinities of Timor's Austronesian languages: a preliminary investigation." ''Studies in Languages and Cultures of East Timor'' 1:97-202. * Taber, Mark (1993). "[https://www.jstor.org/stable/3623199 Toward a Better Understanding of the Indigenous Languages of Southwestern Maluku]." ''Oceanic Linguistics'', Vol. 32, No. 2 (Winter, 1993), pp. 389–441. University of Hawai'i.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080119191225/http://www.asianlang.mq.edu.au/INL/langs.html The Languages of East Timor: Some Basic Facts] (Revised 24.8.2004) Geoffrey Hull
{{Central Malayo-Polynesian languages}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Timor-Babar languages}} [[Category:Languages of Indonesia]] [[Category:Languages of East Timor]] [[Category:Timor–Babar languages| ]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox language |name=Wahgi |nativename= |states=[[Papua New Guinea]] |region=[[Western Highlands Province]] |speakers=86,000 |date=1999 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Papuan |fam1=[[Trans–New Guinea languages|Trans–New Guinea]] |fam2=[[Chimbu–Wahgi languages|Chimbu–Wahgi]] |fam3=[[Wahgi languages]] |lc1=wgi|ld1=Mid-Wahgi |lc2=whg|ld2=North Wahgi |glotto=nucl1620 |glottoname=Nuclear Wahgi |glotto2=nort2921 |glottoname2=North Wahgi }} '''Wahgi''' is a [[Trans–New Guinea languages|Trans–New Guinea language]] of the [[Chimbu–Wahgi languages|Chimbu–Wahgi branch]] spoken by approximately 100,000 people in the highlands of [[Papua New Guinea]]. Like other [[Chimbu languages]], Wahgi has some unusual [[lateral consonant]]s. == Phonology == ===Consonants=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |+Wahgi consonantsPhillips 1976 |- ! colspan=3| ! [[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ! [[Dental consonant|(palatalized)
dental]]Presumed readings of palatalized allophones {{angbr|{{IPA|tš̪ š̪ ň̪}}}} etc. ! [[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! [[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! [[Velar consonant|Velar]] |- ! colspan=3| [[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | {{IPA|m}} | {{IPA|n̪~n̪ʲ}} | {{IPA|n}} | | {{IPA|ŋ}} |- ! rowspan=2 colspan=2| [[Obstruent consonant|Obstruent]] ! {{small|oral}} | {{IPA|p}} | {{IPA|s̪~ɕ̪}} | {{IPA|t}} | | {{IPA|k}} |- ! {{small|[[prenasalization|prenasalised]]}} | {{IPA|mb}} | {{IPA|n̪d̪z̪~n̪d̪ʑ̪}} | {{IPA|nd}} | | {{IPA|ŋɡ}} |- ! colspan=3| [[Lateral consonant|Lateral]] | | {{IPA|ɬ̪~ɬ̪ʲ}} | {{IPA|ɺ}} | | {{IPA|{{PUA|}}}} |- ! colspan=3| [[Semivowel]] | {{IPA|w}} | | | {{IPA|j}} | |} The dental consonants are "distributed", with closure along a considerable distance of the vocal tract. This presumably means that they are [[laminal consonant|laminal]], and that the alveolar consonants are [[apical consonant|apical]]. The dental consonants have palatalized allophones in free variation. The description of the (palatalized) dentals suggest they may be [[alveolo-palatal]] or something similar. This is further suggested by transitional vowels triggered by {{IPA|/ɬ̪/}}, apparently even by its non-palatalized allophone: {{IPA|/oɬ̪/ [oɪ̯ɬ̪]}} 'moon', {{IPA|/ˈéɬ̪é/ [ˈéɬ̪ɪ̯è]}} [sic] 'here'. The nasal element of the prenasalized consonants is syllabic when not preceded by a vowel, but takes a noncontrastive low tone and is never stressed: {{IPA|/ˈmbà/ [m̩̀ˈba]}} 'but', {{IPA|/ˈpɪ̀ɬ̪mbé/ [ˈpɪ̀ɬ̪m̩̄bé]}} 'we know'. Prenasalized consonants are perceived as single segments word-initially, but as nasal + stop word-medially.Phillips 1976: 54 Nasals and semivowels have no notable allophony, apart from the optional palatalization of {{IPA|/n̪/}}. The other consonants vary markedly, with most variants being positional: {| class="wikitable IPA" style="text-align:center;" |+Consonantal allophones |- ! !! word-initial!!word-medial!!word-final !word-initial,
phrase-medial!!word-final,
phrase-medial |- !/p/ |p~b
pʷ~bʷRealized as labial before a vowel sequence {{IPA|/uˈi/}} or {{IPA|/uˈɪ/}} (with stress on the {{IPA|/i/}} or {{IPA|/ɪ/}}): {{IPA|/puˈi/}} = {{IPA|[ˈpʷi~ˈbʷi]}}, {{IPA|/suˈi/}} = {{IPA|[ˈs̪ʷi]}}, etc. |p~b |pʰ~ɸ | |pʰ~ɸ~pᵊ{{IPA|[(m)pᵊ]}} an option before an obstruent |- !/mb/ |ᵐp~ᵐb||mp~mb||mpʰ~mɸ | ||mpʰ~mɸ~mpᵊ |- !/s/ |t̪~t̪s̪~s̪~t̪ɕ~ɕ
s̪ʷ |t̪s̪~s̪~t̪ɕ~ɕ
t̪{{IPA|[t̪]}} only appears word-medially as the second member of a consonant cluster |t̪s̪~s̪~t̪ɕ~ɕ | |Final {{IPA|[s̪]}} appears before a following {{IPA|[ɾ, r]}} |- !/nz/ |ⁿd̪~ⁿd̪z̪~ⁿd̪ʑ~ⁿt̪~ⁿt̪s̪~ⁿt̪ɕ |n̪d̪~n̪d̪z̪~n̪d̪ʑ~n̪t̪~n̪t̪s̪~n̪t̪ɕ |n̪t̪~n̪t̪s̪~n̪t̪ɕ~n̪s̪~n̪ɕ |- !/t/ |t~d
tʷ
|ɾ~r |r̥ |t~dFollowing alveolars, velars, nasals (except /nz/) and laterals
ɾ~rFollowing vowels, bilabials and sibilants (including /nz/) |ɾ~r~r̥
t̚before {{IPA|[n]}} |- !/nd/ |ⁿt~ⁿd |nt~nd |ntʰ | |ntʰ~ntᵊ |- !/k/ |k~ɡ
kʷ~ɡʷ/k/ is labialized not just before {{IPA|/ui/}} and {{IPA|/uɪ/}}, but before /o/ when that /o/ is followed by /n/ or {{IPA|/n̪/}} (unless the nasal is then followed by /e/), or by /nd/ or /nz/ regardless of the next vowel, as in {{IPA|/kon/}} 'bag' and {{IPA|/konze/}} 'ball' but not {{IPA|/kone/}} 'place'. |k~ɡ
ŋ (?)The text says "{{IPA|/k/}} occurs in free variation with {{IPA|/ŋ/}} following word-initial vowel." It is unclear what this is supposed to mean. The illustrative examples show {{IPA|[k~ɡ]}} in {{IPA|/ˈpàkám/ [ˈpàkám, ˈpàɡám]}} 'forked branch' but only {{IPA|[ŋ]}} in {{IPA|/ˈmòkínè/ [ˈmòŋínè]}} 'food', neither of which match the wording for free variation with {{IPA|/ŋ/}}. |kʰ | | |- !/ng/ |ᵑk~ᵑɡ
ᵑɡʷ |ŋk~ŋɡ |(does not occur) |- !ɬ̪ |rowspan=3|(do not occur) |ɬ̪ˢ̪a "voiceless dental fricative lateral with voiceless [[Grooved fricative|grooved]] dental fricative release"~ɬ̪~ɮ̪ |ɬ̪ˢ̪~ɬ̪ | | |- !/ɺ/ |ɺ̥~{{PUA|}}̥~{{PUA|}}̥tʰ~{{PUA|}}̥tr̥~{{PUA|}}̥r̥~ɺ~{{PUA|}}d |ɺ̥~{{PUA|}}̥~{{PUA|}}̥tʰ~{{PUA|}}̥tr̥~{{PUA|}}̥r̥ | | |- !/{{PUA|}}/ |{{PUA|}}~k{{PUA|}}~ʟ̝~ɢ̆A [[velar lateral flap]] {{IPA|[ʟ̆]}} occurs in Kanite and Melpa, so perhaps the flap here is also lateral. |{{PUA|}}~k{{PUA|}} | | |} The southern Kuma dialect has these three laterals, though the alveolar is rather uncommon. (The northern Danga dialect has two laterals, dental fricative and alveolar flap.) The dental and velar laterals assimilate to {{IPA|[ɬ]}} or {{IPA|[ɬ̪]}} before dental and alveolar consonants; the alveolar only to {{IPA|[ɬ]}} before alveolar consonants. In locational forms with a suffix beginning with /t/, the /t/ is elided following the lateral, so that on the surface Wahgi distinguishes dental vs alveolar lateral fricatives and alveolar lateral fricatives vs flaps. ===Vowels=== {| class="wikitable" style=text-align:center |+Wahgi vowels |- ! ! [[Front vowel|Front]] ! [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! [[Close vowels|Close]] | {{IPA|i}} | {{IPA|u}} |- ! [[Mid vowels|Mid]] | {{IPA|ɪ}} | {{IPA|ɔ}} |- ! [[Open vowels|Open]] | {{IPA|e}} | {{IPA|ä}} |} :{{IPA|/a/}} appears as {{IPA|[ä]}} in all positions except before /k/ and /p/, where it is {{IPA|[ɐ]}}. In medial position it is in occasional free variation with {{IPA|[æ]}}. :{{IPA|/ɔ/}} appears as {{IPA|[ɔ]}} in all positions except before nasals, where it is {{IPA|[ɒ]}}. Word-finally it is in free variation with {{IPA|[o]}}. :{{IPA|/u/}} is reduced to labialization ({{IPA|[ʷ]}}) between {{IPA|/p t s k ng/}} and stressed {{IPA|/i/}} or {{IPA|/ɪ/}}. All vowels neutralize to {{IPA|[ɪ̈]}} in final unstressed closed syllables (disregarding subsequent "clitics"). In rapid speech, unstressed {{IPA|/u, ɪ, e/}} elide between stressed syllables. For example, in rapid speech {{IPA|/ˈpetepˈka/}} is pronounced {{IPA|[ˈpeɾpˈka]}}. ===Tone and stress=== Wahgi appears to have three [[word tone]]s rather than phonemic tone on each syllable. At least one syllable will have a phonetic high tone, with the resulting patterns of high, rising and falling on words of one or two syllables, and peaking, rising and falling on words of three to five syllables. Stress also appears to be contrastive, but analysis is difficult. On both monosyllabic and disyllabic words, the three tones are realized as high, rising and falling: [HH], [LH] and [HL]. An analysis of two phonemic syllable tones, HIGH and LOW, is complicated by the appearance of all three word tones on monosyllables with final occlusive codas (and phonetically short vowels).Monosyllables with falling tone are transcribed with low tone in Phillips 1976. In polysyllabic words, *HIGH (H) is phonetically high, optionally extra high on stressed syllables. *LOW (L) is phonetically falling on unstressed syllables at the end of a prosodic phrase. It is phonetically mid between a high tone and another low tone (i.e. the sequence /HLL/ is [HML] and /LLH/ is [LMH]). It is phonetically low elsewhere. On trisyllables, the patterns LHL, HLL, and LLH are attested. On tetrasyllables are LLHL, LLLH, and LHHL (that is, LMHL, LLMH, LHHL). On pentasyllables, only two patterns have been found, LLHHH and LLHHL (that is, LMHHH and LMHHL). Words with six to nine syllables are only attested with a single pattern, a peaking tone (LHL) on the first three syllables followed by a falling tone (LH) stretched out over the remaining syllables. For words of six syllables, this is realized as LHLHLL (phonetically LHLHML); for seven, LHLHLLL; for eight, LHLHHLLL; for nine LHLHHLLLL. In each case, the second syllable (the first high tone) is also stressed, and it is not clear if these are actually double-peaking tones or single peaking tones with preceding stress. Regardless, there does not appear to be any phonemic distinction. ===Phonotactics=== The maximal syllable in Wahgi is CVCC; the minimal syllable is V, which may be any vowel but {{IPA|/ɪ/}}. Any consonant may occur in the onset except the three laterals. Any consonant may occur in the coda except the semivowels and /ng/. With a coda consonant cluster, the first consonant may only be {{IPA|/p, t, k, l̪, ʟ/}} (the two common laterals) and the second may only be {{IPA|/m, s/}}. A word may be anywhere from one to nine syllables long. A monosyllabic word may be any type of syllable but V and maybe CV. (Phonetic length and perhaps tone distribution suggests that words transcribed as CV monosyllables may actually be CVV with identical vowels.) Beside the syllable-onset and -coda restrictions, {{IPA|/i, ɪ/}} may not occur word-initially and {{IPA|/ɪ/}} may not occur word-finally. Observed vowel clusters within words are {{IPA|/i.a, i.o, i.u; ɪ.i, ɪ.o; e.i, e.o, e.u; a.i, a.ɪ, a.e, a.a, a.u; o.i, o.o; u.i, u.ɪ, u.a, u.o, u.u/}}. In some cases (such as {{IPA|/ɪ.i/}}) these sequences reduce across morpheme boundaries, and stress seems to play a role in vowel reduction. It may be that some of the difficulties in analyzing stress may be a conflation of vowel sequences across syllables with sequences in single heavy (bimoraic CVV) syllables. Observed consonant clusters within words are those allowed as syllable codas, {{IPA|/ps, pm, tm, ks, km, l̪s, l̪m, ʟm/}}, plus {{IPA|/p.p, p.t, p.nz; mb.p, mb.t, mb.m; t.p, t.mb, t.nd, t.n̪, t.n, t.ŋ; nd.p, nd.m; k.p; s.p, s.mb, s.nd, s.k, s.nz, s.m, s.n; nz.p, nz.m; m.p, m.nz, m.m, m.ŋ; n̪.p, n̪.m; n.p, n.m, n.ŋ; ŋ.p, ŋ.mb, ŋ.s, ŋ.nz, ŋ.m, ŋ.n; l̪.p, l̪.mb, l̪.t, l̪.k, l̪ [sic], l̪.w; l.mb, l.nd; ʟ.p, ʟ.mb, ʟ.t, ʟ.nz, ʟ.n, ʟ.ŋ, ʟ.w/}}. In rapid speech, the following additional combinations are known: {{IPA|/ks.mp, ks.n, ks.m, ps.nd, lm.ŋ, tm.ŋ/}}. ==Dictionary== The first dictionary of Middle Wahgi was published by [[Church of the Nazarene]] medical missionary [[Evelyn Ramsey]] in 1975.{{cite journal|title=REVIEWS|first=Marie|last=Reay|date=1 March 1977|journal=Oceania|volume=47|issue=3|pages=245–246|doi=10.1002/j.1834-4461.1977.tb01291.x}}{{cite book|author=Gerald H. Anderson|title=Biographical Dictionary of Christian Missions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oQ8BFk9K0ToC&pg=PA596|year=1999|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|isbn=978-0-8028-4680-8|pages=557–}} ==References== *Phillips, Donald (1976) ''Wahgi phonology and morphology''. Pacific linguistics B, issue 36 {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www-01.sil.org/pacific/png/pubs/0000357/Wahgi.pdf Organised Phonology Data] * [http://www-01.sil.org/pacific/png/pubs/928474523814/4_Yu_We.pdf Wahgi orthography, phonology, word list and sample passage] * [[Paradisec]] has [http://catalog.paradisec.org.au/collections/search?language_code=wgi a number of collections that include Wahgi language materials], including one from [[Stephen Wurm|Stephen A Wurm]] ([http://catalog.paradisec.org.au/collections/SAW3 SAW3]). {{Languages of Papua New Guinea}} {{Chimbu–Wahgi languages}} [[Category:Chimbu–Wahgi languages]] [[Category:Languages of Western Highlands Province]] [[Category:Languages of Simbu Province]] [[Category:Languages of Madang Province]] [[Category:Tonal languages]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox writer | name = Yakub Kolas
Якуб Колас | image = Yakub Kolas in office.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = Kanstantsin Mihaylavich Mitskievich | birth_date = {{OldStyleDate|November 3|1882|October 22}} | birth_place = [[Stoŭbtsy|Akinchytsy]], now part of [[Stoŭbtsy]], Belarus | death_date = August 13, 1956 | death_place = [[Minsk]], [[Byelorussian SSR]], [[USSR]] | occupation = Poet and writer | nationality = [[Belarusians|Belarusian]] | period = 1906–1956 | genre = | subject = | movement = | influences = | influenced = | signature = | website = }} '''Yakub Kolas''' (also '''Jakub Kołas''', {{lang-be|Яку́б Ко́лас}}, {{OldStyleDate|November 3|1882|October 22}} – August 13, 1956), real name Kanstancin Mickievič (Міцке́віч Канстанці́н Міха́йлавіч) was a Belarusian writer, People's Poet of the [[Byelorussian SSR]] (1926), and member (1928) and vice-president (from 1929) of the [[Belarusian Academy of Sciences]]. In his works, Yakub Kolas was known for his sympathy towards the ordinary Belarusian peasantry. This was evident in his pen name 'Kolas', meaning 'ear of grain' in Belarusian. He wrote collections of poems ''Songs of Captivity'' (1908) and ''Songs of Grief'' ({{lang-be|Песьні-жальбы}}, 1910), poems ''A New Land'' ({{lang-be|Новая зямля}}, 1923) and ''Simon the Musician'' ({{lang-be|Сымон-музыка}}, 1925), stories, and plays. His poem ''The Fisherman's Hut'' ({{lang-be|Рыбакова хата}}, 1947) is about the fight after unification of Belarus with the Soviet state. His trilogy ''At a Crossroads'' (1954) is about the pre-Revolutionary life of the Belarusian peasantry and the democratic intelligentsia. He was awarded the [[Stalin Prize]] in 1946 and 1949. In honor of Yakub Kolas, a [[Yakub Kolas Square|square]] and a [[Yakub Kolas Street|street]] in the center of [[Minsk]] bear his name. [[Image:Belarus-Minsk-Yakub Kolas Square-2.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Yakub Kolas Monument in [[Minsk]]]] {{Commons category|Yakub Kolas}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kolas, Yakub}} [[Category:1882 births]] [[Category:1956 deaths]] [[Category:People from Stowbtsy]] [[Category:People from Minsk Governorate]] [[Category:Communist Party of the Soviet Union members]] [[Category:Members of the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Belarusian writers]] [[Category:20th-century Belarusian poets]] [[Category:Belarusian-language writers]] [[Category:Socialist realism writers]] [[Category:Academicians of the Byelorussian SSR Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Stalin Prize winners]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Lenin]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Red Banner]] [[Category:Belarusian male poets]]
